text: I go, or I am going in French, is je vais.
You'll notice how this is very different to the other forms we've introduced.
Again, what was to go?
Allez.
And you go?
Vous allez.
And we go?
Nous allons.
So, they all start with A, and they all have A double L at the beginning.
They're very similar to one another.
But then suddenly we get to I go, I am going, which is je vais.
So, how would you say I'm going to do it?
Je vais le faire.
How would you say I'm going to go?
Je vais aller.
I'm going to go there.
Je vais y aller.
Again, typically when French people say something like I'm going to go, they will include the word there.
So, the E will be included.
Even in sentences where in English you're more likely to say just I'm going to go, without bothering about the there.
How would you say I'm going to eat?
Je vais manger.
I'm going to eat this evening.
Je vais manger ce soir.
I'm going to eat later.
Je vais manger plus tard.
What do you think he is going will be?
Il va.
Most probably you'll have said il va.
The reason for this is, is the pattern we've been following is I, he and she have all been the same.
However, for to go, for going, it's different.
It's less regular, less typical, less easy to predict.
But we'll get plenty of practice here so that it becomes second nature.
So again, what is he goes, he is going?
Il va.
So in that case, what would she goes, she is going be?
Elle va.
How about you in formula going?
Tu va.
Again, make sure when you're pronouncing tu, to do so with your lips rounded.
Practice, try whistling first if you want.
Round your lips and say the letter T, but with your lips still rounded.
And it should come out like this.
Tu.
Has that slightly unusual sound that we don't have in English.
So, how would you say you are going to buy it?
Tu va l'acheter.
So again, to buy is...
Acheter.
And to buy it...
L'acheter.
See how the abbreviation happens.
You have two vowels touching.
You have the L-E from it.
And you have the A from acheter.
And so of course, you don't have two vowels touching here.
Instead, you abbreviate it and you have L'acheter.
So, how would you say again, you're going to buy it?
Tu vas l'acheter.
Using the rising intonation, how would you say...
You're going to buy it?
Are you going to buy it?
Tu vas l'acheter.
And let's try also by using is it that?
Is it that you're going to buy it?
Est-ce que tu vas l'acheter?
Is it that you're going to buy some of it?
Yes.
Est-ce que tu vas en acheter?
So again, what is to go?
Aller.
And how would you say you go or you are going formal, using vous?
Vous allez.
What about we go or we are going?
Nous allons.
So let's call that the A group.
That's the ones that begin with A.
But of course, there are also those ones that begin with V,
the V group that we've been looking at.
Let's look at those again as well.
How would you say I go or I am going?
Je vais.
But he goes would be...
Il va.
She goes.
Elle va.
You, in formal, are going.
Tu vas.
Tu vas.
Finally, we have they are going.
That also belongs to the V group.
The earlier tricks we've used to find out what the they form is will not work here.
Because again, to go in French is too irregular, too unusual.
But as I said, we'll get lots of practice with it, so it will become second nature.
They are going in French is...
Ils vont.
Ils vont.
Spelt V-O-N-T.
Think of Volavant.
So how would you say they are going to eat?
Ils vont manger.
What's to wait in French, to wait?
Attendre.
They're going to wait.
They're going to wait for me.
They're going to wait for me.
They're going to wait for me.
Again, you may have made the mistake to say attendre pour moi, which is very common for English speakers.
But of course, attendre in French is a little more like the English to await.
So how would you say to await me?
M'attendre.
So here we have the me and the attendre.
But of course, the M-E from the me, the me, you have two vowels touching there with the A from attendre.
And so it abbreviates and you end up with...
M'attendre.
So again, how would you say they are going to wait for me?
Ils vont m'attendre.
How about they're not going to wait for me?
Ils ne vont pas m'attendre.
Let's now try an all-female group.
They're not going to wait for me.
Elles ne vont pas m'attendre.
So one more time.
What was to go?
Aller.
You go or you are going?
With the formal, the vous form.
Vous allez.
We go or we are going?
Nous allons.
Now going over to the V group, how would you say I go or I am going?
Je vais.
He goes or he is going.
Il va.
She goes or she is going.
Elle va.
You, in formal, go or are going.
Tu vas.
They are going.
Ils vont.
They, an entire female group, are going.
Elles vont.
Thank you.
